author: iSazonov
body:
### Problem
It is impossible to build and debug from VS Code on Windows - VS Code cannot find pwsh.exe.
### Fix
Use powershell.exe on Windows to build.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: `pwsh` should be in the PATH with beta.9

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: What if I don't install Beta.9?

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: But isn't this file only used with PSCore6?  Eventually we will only support the final release which will be called pwsh.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
By default Windows don't have pwsh.exe installed. Currently we can not build PowerShell Core 6.0 on Windows from VS Code until we install PowerShell Core 6.0 >=Beta.9 but can from command line. On Unix we have to install PowerShell Core 6.0 in any case because we deprecate install.sh. 
So question is - Shall we continue support build PowerShell Core with Windows PowerShell or no? If we continue build from command line why we don't support to build from VS Code?

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @iSazonov I see.  I wasn't thinking about the initial bootstrap issue, however, it would seem like this is an edge case as we're getting closer to a final version of 6.0.0.  I expect the significant majority of people building PSCore6 to be using the build.psm1 module.  The only time I ever build PSCore6 from VSCode is when debugging something.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: We should document if PowerShell Core 6.0 is mandatory prerequest on Windows now or better add in BootStrap (check latest version?).

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body:
I like the suggestion to have it in `Start-PSBootStrap`.  Created issue https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/5367

I'll submit a doc update: https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/5368

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: Ok, I close the PR because we'll have `pwsh.exe` with `Start-PSBootStrap`.

title: Replace pwsh with powershell in VS Code tasks.json for Windows
